title: I'm terrible at unlocked screen >.>
body:
A lot of people use unlocked screen, it's easier to aim and dodge skillshots, manually attackmove, last hit and helps with map awareness.
I've tried it for a few months. It was incredibly uncomfortable to have to look & click at more than just the centre of the screen though I've moved on from panning and going where tf did my champ go.

So I've settled for using unlocked screen to just look around and farm and locked for teamfights and such for concentration.
Should I continue learning to play with unlocked screen?

Thanks for all the tips everyone!

replies.body:
Honestly, there isn't a "Real" downside to playing with a locked screen as long as you move it to look around and such.

There are plenty of people in higher elos (Plat and above) that will use locked screen (and there are medical reasons to as well)

I personally do as well and i don't see a real issue with locked screen.

Playing with an unlocked screen is definitely worth the effort. It allows a Top Laner to check for Teleport opportunities, a Jungler to easily survey the landscape and, as you've already said, can improve map awareness and your ability to target beyond the edge of your screen. 

As with anything in League though, it requires practice. Having played the game for nearly 6 years I'll admit that I sometimes manage to push the mouse too far to a side and end up losing track of where I am. However, most of the time it is a major reason why I was able to assist my team in time or barely escape a gank.

It definitely isn't for everyone, just as playing locked gives me a headache, but if you can manage to add it to your repertoire of skills you'll more than occasionally notice the benefits.

Spacebar is your friend with unlocked screen. It locks it so long as you are holding it (assuming you haven't changed the default bind). You are very limited playing with a perma locked screen, I really would recommend creating new better habits than sticking with the old sub par ones because they are easier for you.

=> RTS players or those who've had experiences with the genre generally familiarise themselves with the unlocked screen much easier.
=> Those who are more experiences with Hack n' Slash ARPGs like say Diablo for instance, tend to find locked screen closer to home to use.

However in this game where control over the map is more important than seeing what's going around your toon, it's no secret that unlocked screen has an innate advantage in LoL.

Much like Gimble has said, just keep playing in unlocked. You'll get around it sooner or later.

A couple tricks to use in unlocked screen that might benefit the players:

* The Space key is defaulted to bring the camera back to your character in the unlocked screen mode. So you can always look elsewhere to scout or whatever and press Space to immediately jump the camera back to you afterwards. Also, during unlocked screen mode, holding the Space key would function identically as locked screen for the duration of the holding.
* When using spells with large range, such as Pantheon's R: You could move your camera to the destination to which you wanna cast the spell to move the character to, and hover your cursor over the R (or any spell) without pressing it which the range of your spell will be displayed visually onto the game hence you can physically see how far the destination is from the included range. This is useful to help one plan long ranged assaults across the map for the champions that can do it without having to guess your precise range or being restricted to probing around the minimap every single time.

>=> RTS players or those who've had experiences with the genre generally familiarise themselves with the unlocked screen much easier.

> Spacebar is your friend with unlocked screen. It locks it so long as you are holding it.


Exactly this. 

Also try lowering your panning speed. I'm fairly certain you can only change this while in a match, so start up an empty custom match and try different speeds to see if a slower one than the default is more comfortable. 

Keep in mind, pressing spacebar will snap your screen to focus your Champion (it will not always be in the direct centre, for example, if you are near the 'top' of the map, your Champion will appear slightly higher than the centre so that more of the playable map is displayed). 
Along with using your spacebar, just when you are returning to lane or rotating, you should want to look at the focus of the map (maybe bot lane if you're a top laner with teleport, or dragon pit if you're returning to mid or bot), while also keeping track of your Champion on the minimap as well. Becoming familiar with the minimap and using it as frequently as possible will just help your macro play out immensely. 

Another quick tip, you can also lock your screen to your teammates by using the F1 through to F5 keys, I'm not sure if the F keys refer to the position of your teammates on the scoreboard, but it's so helpful to quickly glance at your other teammates and their situation for deciding on ganks and roams as a jungler, and even as a laner. 

Good luck on the Rift fellow Summoner :D
I usually use unlocked screen, but I do switch to unlocked when playing champs like kalista and twitch, where you are needed to move a lot and focus on yourself a lot more

I use a Razer Naga, all my abilities/items/etc are bound to the buttons on the side of the mouse with ALT/SHIFT/CTRL being used for modifiers.

This frees up a hand to use the arrow keys to move the screen.

If you're going to play a game where you are at it for long periods of time, you're best off getting decent equipment.

A form fitting gaming mouse, a keyboard with wrist support, and a comfortable and supporting chair.
